content: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/"
quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/"
reply: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs.
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: quote: he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. ????? what do you mean be choosing doing what is right for the nation's defense OR the machinist union and CT jobs? They are one and the same. In case you havent been keeping up with current events the USAF's F-15 fleet shrinks by several airframes per month and will be less than 200 airframes by 2012. The F-22 is the ONLY aircraft in the USAF inventory that is superior to the Su30/35 that is being sold to those the US could potentially face in a conflict, including Iran which hopes to get it starting this year. The Su30 now has an RA coatings pkg as an option that give it the same RCS as the F-35 and its no secret that the Su35 can run circles around the F-35 in any given situation. The MiG35 version of the MiG29 series is even more of a threat that no one has acknowledged because no one has purchased it yet. It can be built to have a lower RCS than the F-35 and has far better performance than the Su30 and the only thing that prevents this low cost fighter(28 million) from being bought aggressively is that Mikoyan has become the red headed step child of Russia's aviation industry in which Sukhoi gets the lion's share of military money through the newly formed consortium. Australia, Japan and Israel ALL would much prefer getting F-22s instead of the lousy, years behind schedule and pitifully performing F-35. Exporting the F-22 would guarantee over 20,000 jobs for years to come.
quote: he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs.
reply: ????? what do you mean be choosing doing what is right for the nation's defense OR the machinist union and CT jobs? They are one and the same. In case you havent been keeping up with current events the USAF's F-15 fleet shrinks by several airframes per month and will be less than 200 airframes by 2012. The F-22 is the ONLY aircraft in the USAF inventory that is superior to the Su30/35 that is being sold to those the US could potentially face in a conflict, including Iran which hopes to get it starting this year. The Su30 now has an RA coatings pkg as an option that give it the same RCS as the F-35 and its no secret that the Su35 can run circles around the F-35 in any given situation. The MiG35 version of the MiG29 series is even more of a threat that no one has acknowledged because no one has purchased it yet. It can be built to have a lower RCS than the F-35 and has far better performance than the Su30 and the only thing that prevents this low cost fighter(28 million) from being bought aggressively is that Mikoyan has become the red headed step child of Russia's aviation industry in which Sukhoi gets the lion's share of military money through the newly formed consortium. Australia, Japan and Israel ALL would much prefer getting F-22s instead of the lousy, years behind schedule and pitifully performing F-35. Exporting the F-22 would guarantee over 20,000 jobs for years to come.
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/" Why do you think cancelling the F-22 is "the right thing for national defense"? The F-22 is supposed to be the F-15 replacement, not the jack-of-all-trades-master-of-none F-35. WHile I think the F-35 might be a little better than Flanker acknowledges, it still is not an air superiority fighter. The ONLY aiframe that outclasses other current new production fighters is the F-22. And we are not buy enough of them. SO do the math; retire 500 or so F-15s and buy 187 replacements. Do you honestly believe that is enough? About 40% of congress doesn't believe so. The CSAF doesn't think so. Long-range planners do not think so. SO go ahead. rant about no real threats out there. But since crystal balls really do not work, knowing the exact threat 10 or 15 years down the road is best left to those who do the analysis. And how can you make that "doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs" statement when we are giving free money to practically any entity that wants it under the guise of economic stimulus?
quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/"
reply: Why do you think cancelling the F-22 is "the right thing for national defense"? The F-22 is supposed to be the F-15 replacement, not the jack-of-all-trades-master-of-none F-35. WHile I think the F-35 might be a little better than Flanker acknowledges, it still is not an air superiority fighter. The ONLY aiframe that outclasses other current new production fighters is the F-22. And we are not buy enough of them. SO do the math; retire 500 or so F-15s and buy 187 replacements. Do you honestly believe that is enough? About 40% of congress doesn't believe so. The CSAF doesn't think so. Long-range planners do not think so. SO go ahead. rant about no real threats out there. But since crystal balls really do not work, knowing the exact threat 10 or 15 years down the road is best left to those who do the analysis. And how can you make that "doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs" statement when we are giving free money to practically any entity that wants it under the guise of economic stimulus?
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: If Dodd wants to continue the F-22 program then I beg the almighty Obama to cancel it. STFU Dodd. You will soon be history.
reply: If Dodd wants to continue the F-22 program then I beg the almighty Obama to cancel it. STFU Dodd. You will soon be history.
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat.
reply: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat.

content: quote: which will likely never engage in air to air combat. And your crystal ball told you that? What happens in 10 years if Saudi Arabia, UAE or any other countries now flying and currently receiving newer versions of the F-15 than is the USAF decide they have sucked all the money they can from us and close the oil spiggot and then after crippling the US economy through 400/bbl oil they decide they want to attack and destroy Israel or other US interests in the name of power and control? What if the EU breaks down and war erupts in Europe(it COULD happen in 10 years with the present rate of Islamic influx in France, GB, and Sweden) WHat would you suppose can keep the edge against unpredictable foes? 30 year old F-15s? F-35s? WHat about China? at their current rate of military buildup and the US proposed drastic cuts they can be in a position to take Taiwan within 5-7 years. They have 400+ Su27s which are F-15 equals of which there will be less than 1/3rd of that number of F-15s in USAF inventory, not to mention they will have over 1000 NEW domestically produced aircraft in that period. WAKE THE FUQ UP. Obama is making the US weaker so other countries wont see it as a threat. who will then decide to take advantage of that new weakness? But hey, at least illegals will still get welfare and unemployment benefits will have been extended to 5 years and thats more important...right?

content: quote: And of course the number one reason other countries will attack us is because we have 300 F-22s instead of 500. It all makes sense now. It still amazes me that some think we all live in fairy tale land where wars dont exist and people would never want to see the US fall To use a phrase that Hussein loves to say, MAKE NO MISTAKE, LETS BE CLEAR, the ONLY reason that no one dares fuq with the USA is because of its massive military power and ability to project force abroad. The US has an obvious deterrent to other nations that seek its demise. If and when the US is perceived as being unable to protect its interests both at home and abroad then that weakness WILL BE(not maybe)exploited. WHy do you think that the Somali pirates continue to attack ships? They KNOW no one will come on to their turf and do anything about it and as long as folks pay millions they wont stop. They think America is weak because of Clintoon's follies and do not fear the west. Russian leadership has been on cloud 9 since Gates made his announcement of canceling the F-22 and they know the next 4 years will result in drastic reductions of US military power. Once Russia realizes that Obama is a paper tiger and the military cuts are made, then they will do what they please, when they please and will tell the US to shut the FuQ up. Obama has been a source of much amusement and hearty laughter in the Kremlin these days.

content: quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat. Look around, you can say that about a lot of weapons systems we have. The point in having a fighter that outclasses everyone else is that maybe you will not have to use it, but if you do, it will come out on top. And since you are all-knowing, what happens in 10-15 years when an advesary with first rate acft has to be dealt with? And what do you propose to replace the F-15 fleet with? Or are one of those that thinks we dod not need a dedicated air superiority fighter? The problem with your vision is that it does not look past tomorrow. BTW - you left out three VERY important acft in your selections; C-5, KC-135, KC-10. Oh and a sizable percentage of USAF CAS missions have been flown by F-16s.

content: quote: Originally posted by FlankerFlyer: quote: which will likely never engage in air to air combat. And your crystal ball told you that? What happens in 10 years if Saudi Arabia, UAE or any other countries now flying and currently receiving newer versions of the F-15 than is the USAF decide they have sucked all the money they can from us and close the oil spiggot and then after crippling the US economy through 400/bbl oil they decide they want to attack and destroy Israel or other US interests in the name of power and control? You fail to mention that we outspend China and every other country by a massive proportion. Also the fact that our strong economic ties make war less and less likely. Again, looking at the years since WWII, when was the last time the US went to war with a country they had very strong economic and financial ties with? All that being said, no where in my original post did I say that we shouldn't buy new aircraft. My point is that we are stuck on buying aircraft to fight WWIII while we are heavily engaged in two smaller wars. We should place the PRIORITY on fighter the war today, not the war ten years from now. Also, the C-5 is on it's way out and I did cap the number at 3 to avoid naming every aircraft in our inventory. The reason the F-16 has performed so many CAS missions is because we don't have enough true attack aircraft and there is no other role for the fighter.

title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/"
quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/"
reply: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs.
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: quote: he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. ????? what do you mean be choosing doing what is right for the nation's defense OR the machinist union and CT jobs? They are one and the same. In case you havent been keeping up with current events the USAF's F-15 fleet shrinks by several airframes per month and will be less than 200 airframes by 2012. The F-22 is the ONLY aircraft in the USAF inventory that is superior to the Su30/35 that is being sold to those the US could potentially face in a conflict, including Iran which hopes to get it starting this year. The Su30 now has an RA coatings pkg as an option that give it the same RCS as the F-35 and its no secret that the Su35 can run circles around the F-35 in any given situation. The MiG35 version of the MiG29 series is even more of a threat that no one has acknowledged because no one has purchased it yet. It can be built to have a lower RCS than the F-35 and has far better performance than the Su30 and the only thing that prevents this low cost fighter(28 million) from being bought aggressively is that Mikoyan has become the red headed step child of Russia's aviation industry in which Sukhoi gets the lion's share of military money through the newly formed consortium. Australia, Japan and Israel ALL would much prefer getting F-22s instead of the lousy, years behind schedule and pitifully performing F-35. Exporting the F-22 would guarantee over 20,000 jobs for years to come.
quote: he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs.
reply: ????? what do you mean be choosing doing what is right for the nation's defense OR the machinist union and CT jobs? They are one and the same. In case you havent been keeping up with current events the USAF's F-15 fleet shrinks by several airframes per month and will be less than 200 airframes by 2012. The F-22 is the ONLY aircraft in the USAF inventory that is superior to the Su30/35 that is being sold to those the US could potentially face in a conflict, including Iran which hopes to get it starting this year. The Su30 now has an RA coatings pkg as an option that give it the same RCS as the F-35 and its no secret that the Su35 can run circles around the F-35 in any given situation. The MiG35 version of the MiG29 series is even more of a threat that no one has acknowledged because no one has purchased it yet. It can be built to have a lower RCS than the F-35 and has far better performance than the Su30 and the only thing that prevents this low cost fighter(28 million) from being bought aggressively is that Mikoyan has become the red headed step child of Russia's aviation industry in which Sukhoi gets the lion's share of military money through the newly formed consortium. Australia, Japan and Israel ALL would much prefer getting F-22s instead of the lousy, years behind schedule and pitifully performing F-35. Exporting the F-22 would guarantee over 20,000 jobs for years to come.
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Senator Dodd appears to be caught again in the crossfire. With a tough race to retain his senate seat in 2010 and already damaged by his lie concerning his responsibility for the bonus exception in the Stimulus Bill, he now has to choose between doing right for the nation's defense ... or doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs. quote: Facing a potentially tough election in 2010, Connecticut Sen. Chris Dodd rallied Thursday to the side of union members in his state whose jobs are at risk under an Obama administration budget proposal. "I'm here today to tell you that I'll do everything I can ... to make our case to our colleagues. That is where the final defense will be for this program," Dodd told members of the Hartford chapter of the International Association of Machinists. The group would take a big hit under Defense Secretary Robert Gates' budget proposal, which calls for halting production of the F-22 jet -- the jet's engines are made in Connecticut. But Dodd, along with Connecticut Rep. John Larson, met with union members Thursday to assure them they'd battle Gates over the issue. Dodd has fought before to save the F-22 program, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, and he said Thursday that party distinction doesn't matter to him at a time when his constituents are worried about keeping food on the table. <more> "http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/04/09/dodd-caught-crossfire-calls-halt-f-production/" Why do you think cancelling the F-22 is "the right thing for national defense"? The F-22 is supposed to be the F-15 replacement, not the jack-of-all-trades-master-of-none F-35. WHile I think the F-35 might be a little better than Flanker acknowledges, it still is not an air superiority fighter. The ONLY aiframe that outclasses other current new production fighters is the F-22. And we are not buy enough of them. SO do the math; retire 500 or so F-15s and buy 187 replacements. Do you honestly believe that is enough? About 40% of congress doesn't believe so. The CSAF doesn't think so. Long-range planners do not think so. SO go ahead. rant about no real threats out there. But since crystal balls really do not work, knowing the exact threat 10 or 15 years down the road is best left to those who do the analysis. And how can you make that "doing right for the machinists' union and CT jobs" statement when we are giving free money to practically any entity that wants it under the guise of economic stimulus?

title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat.
reply: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat.

content: quote: which will likely never engage in air to air combat. And your crystal ball told you that? What happens in 10 years if Saudi Arabia, UAE or any other countries now flying and currently receiving newer versions of the F-15 than is the USAF decide they have sucked all the money they can from us and close the oil spiggot and then after crippling the US economy through 400/bbl oil they decide they want to attack and destroy Israel or other US interests in the name of power and control? What if the EU breaks down and war erupts in Europe(it COULD happen in 10 years with the present rate of Islamic influx in France, GB, and Sweden) WHat would you suppose can keep the edge against unpredictable foes? 30 year old F-15s? F-35s? WHat about China? at their current rate of military buildup and the US proposed drastic cuts they can be in a position to take Taiwan within 5-7 years. They have 400+ Su27s which are F-15 equals of which there will be less than 1/3rd of that number of F-15s in USAF inventory, not to mention they will have over 1000 NEW domestically produced aircraft in that period. WAKE THE FUQ UP. Obama is making the US weaker so other countries wont see it as a threat. who will then decide to take advantage of that new weakness? But hey, at least illegals will still get welfare and unemployment benefits will have been extended to 5 years and thats more important...right?

content: quote: And of course the number one reason other countries will attack us is because we have 300 F-22s instead of 500. It all makes sense now. It still amazes me that some think we all live in fairy tale land where wars dont exist and people would never want to see the US fall To use a phrase that Hussein loves to say, MAKE NO MISTAKE, LETS BE CLEAR, the ONLY reason that no one dares fuq with the USA is because of its massive military power and ability to project force abroad. The US has an obvious deterrent to other nations that seek its demise. If and when the US is perceived as being unable to protect its interests both at home and abroad then that weakness WILL BE(not maybe)exploited. WHy do you think that the Somali pirates continue to attack ships? They KNOW no one will come on to their turf and do anything about it and as long as folks pay millions they wont stop. They think America is weak because of Clintoon's follies and do not fear the west. Russian leadership has been on cloud 9 since Gates made his announcement of canceling the F-22 and they know the next 4 years will result in drastic reductions of US military power. Once Russia realizes that Obama is a paper tiger and the military cuts are made, then they will do what they please, when they please and will tell the US to shut the FuQ up. Obama has been a source of much amusement and hearty laughter in the Kremlin these days.

content: quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat. The point in having a fighter that outclasses everyone else is that maybe you will not have to use it, but if you do, it will come out on top. And since you are all-knowing, what happens in 10-15 years when an advesary with first rate acft has to be dealt with? And what do you propose to replace the F-15 fleet with? Or are one of those that thinks we dod not need a dedicated air superiority fighter? The problem with your vision is that it does not look past tomorrow. BTW - you left out three VERY important acft in your selections; C-5, KC-135, KC-10. Oh and a sizable percentage of USAF CAS missions have been flown by F-16s.

F-35s? WHat about China? at their current rate of military buildup and the US proposed drastic cuts they can be in a position to take Taiwan within 5-7 years. They have 400+ Su27s which are F-15 equals of which there will be less than 1/3rd of that number of F-15s in USAF inventory, not to mention they will have over 1000 NEW domestically produced aircraft in that period. WAKE THE FUQ UP. Obama is making the US weaker so other countries wont see it as a threat. who will then decide to take advantage of that new weakness? But hey, at least illegals will still get welfare and unemployment benefits will have been extended to 5 years and thats more important...right? You fail to mention that we outspend China and every other country by a massive proportion. Also the fact that our strong economic ties make war less and less likely. Again, looking at the years since WWII, when was the last time the US went to war with a country they had very strong economic and financial ties with? All that being said, no where in my original post did I say that we shouldn't buy new aircraft. My point is that we are stuck on buying aircraft to fight WWIII while we are heavily engaged in two smaller wars. We should place the PRIORITY on fighter the war today, not the war ten years from now. "Russian leadership has been on cloud 9 since Gates made his announcement of canceling the F-22 and they know the next 4 years will result in drastic reductions of US military power. Once Russia realizes that Obama is a paper tiger and the military cuts are made, then they will do what they please, when they please and will tell the US to shut the FuQ up." That is total BS. In the first place, Gates isn't canceling the F-22. Not to mention the fact that you constantly overstate the strength of China and Russia. sw614: If you actually read what I wrote, you'd see I mentioned tanker aircraft. Also, the C-5 is on it's way out and I did cap the number at 3 to avoid naming every aircraft in our inventory. The reason the F-16 has performed so many CAS missions is because we don't have enough true attack aircraft and there is no other role for the fighter.
quote: Originally posted by FlankerFlyer: quote: which will likely never engage in air to air combat. And your crystal ball told you that? What happens in 10 years if Saudi Arabia, UAE or any other countries now flying and currently receiving newer versions of the F-15 than is the USAF decide they have sucked all the money they can from us and close the oil spiggot and then after crippling the US economy through 400/bbl oil they decide they want to attack and destroy Israel or other US interests in the name of power and control? What if the EU breaks down and war erupts in Europe(it COULD happen in 10 years with the present rate of Islamic influx in France, GB, and Sweden) WHat would you suppose can keep the edge against unpredictable foes? 30 year old F-15s? F-35s? WHat about China? at their current rate of military buildup and the US proposed drastic cuts they can be in a position to take Taiwan within 5-7 years. They have 400+ Su27s which are F-15 equals of which there will be less than 1/3rd of that number of F-15s in USAF inventory, not to mention they will have over 1000 NEW domestically produced aircraft in that period. WAKE THE FUQ UP. Obama is making the US weaker so other countries wont see it as a threat. who will then decide to take advantage of that new weakness? But hey, at least illegals will still get welfare and unemployment benefits will have been extended to 5 years and thats more important...right?

Again, looking at the years since WWII, when was the last time the US went to war with a country they had very strong economic and financial ties with? All that being said, no where in my original post did I say that we shouldn't buy new aircraft. My point is that we are stuck on buying aircraft to fight WWIII while we are heavily engaged in two smaller wars. We should place the PRIORITY on fighter the war today, not the war ten years from now. "Russian leadership has been on cloud 9 since Gates made his announcement of canceling the F-22 and they know the next 4 years will result in drastic reductions of US military power. Once Russia realizes that Obama is a paper tiger and the military cuts are made, then they will do what they please, when they please and will tell the US to shut the FuQ up." That is total BS. In the first place, Gates isn't canceling the F-22. Not to mention the fact that you constantly overstate the strength of China and Russia. sw614: If you actually read what I wrote, you'd see I mentioned tanker aircraft. Also, the C-5 is on it's way out and I did cap the number at 3 to avoid naming every aircraft in our inventory. The reason the F-16 has performed so many CAS missions is because we don't have enough true attack aircraft and there is no other role for the fighter.
title: Dodd (D,CT) Slams Proposed Cuts to F-22 Program

content: quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat. Just like a wise and sage congressman once wanted to close that U.S. patent office, as all that could possibly have been invented, has been invented... One wonders... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
quote: Originally posted by foxred03: Here's a question for everyone: In your opinion, what Air Force airplanes have been the most important over the last 8 years? I say the A-10, C-130, and C-17. Thus, it seems to me that newer attack and cargo aircraft (along with tankers) should be the priority, not new air superiority fighters, which will likely never engage in air to air combat.
reply: Just like a wise and sage congressman once wanted to close that U.S. patent office, as all that could possibly have been invented, has been invented... One wonders... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

Obama is making the US weaker so other countries wont see it as a threat. who will then decide to take advantage of that new weakness? But hey, at least illegals will still get welfare and unemployment benefits will have been extended to 5 years and thats more important...right? And of course the number one reason other countries will attack us is because we have 300 F-22s instead of 500. It all makes sense now. What 300 F-22s? If SecDef Gates has his way, it will be 187. You are missing the point. What if in a decade or so we have to go against a foe with current acft with better performance who doesn't run? Because we have nukes. And lots of them. Nuclear countries only have to worry about other nuclear countries, and the nukes of those nuclear countries. That philosophy was found to be intellectually vapid, after WW-II... Shortly after WW-II the U.S.A.F. proposed the disestablishment of the U.S.N., the U.S.A. and the U.S.M.C., as we had the "nuclear bomb" and no modern war would require the use of ships, submarines or ground troops ever again... Well, we can certainly see that they were correct in their assumptions... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
